child.geography: Canada, Southwest British Columbia, Pacific Ocean coast of Vancouver Island.

child.pub-comments: 320 speakers (2011 census) out of an ethnic population of 7,760. The language is almost completely replaced by English in both formal and informal domains of use, though significant passive knowledge of the language survives. Ceremonial use. The Nuu-chah-nulth Tribe is recognized by the Canadian government, and the Nuu-chah-nulth language is recognized as an individual language by the First Peoples’ Heritage, Language and Culture Council.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.geography: United States, Washington Olympic Peninsula northern tip, opposite Vancouver Island.
child.pub-comments: 12 speakers (Golla 2007) out of an ethnic population of 2,220 (2000 census). Since late 1970s Makah Cultural and Research Center has sponsored language education at Neah Bay (2007). Elderly only.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.geography: Canada, British Columbia, Malachan Reserve, Nitinaht lake. Also previously used in Pacheedaht Territory in the vicinity of Port Renfrew, British Columbia.
child.pub-comments: 11 speakers (2010 A. Werle) out of an ethnic population of 920. Shifting to English [eng]. Ceremonial Use. The name Ditidaht is commonly used for the traditional language that is shared by the present-day Ditidaht and Pacheedaht, though only the Ditidaht also use the name as an ethnonym. The Ditidaht and Pacheedaht peoples have distinct ethnic identities from each other, as well as distinct ethnolinguistic identities from their most closely related neighbors, the Nuu-chah-nulth [nuk] of Vancouver Island, and the Makah [myh] of the Olympic Peninsula (Washington, United States).

child.geography: Canada, Central British Columbia coast, Bella Bella and Kitasoo villages, Rivers Inlet area.

child.pub-comments: 90 speakers (2011 census) out of an ethnic population of 1,570 (Golla 2007). Speakers 25 and older. Also use English [eng].

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.geography: Canada, British Columbia, North Vancouver Island and adjacent mainland. Also in United States.
child.pub-comments: 500 speakers in Canada (2011 census) and 85 in the United States out of an ethnic population of 3,500 (Golla 2007). Shifting to English [eng]. Speakers 35 and older.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)
child.geography: Canada, Central British Columbia coast inlet, Douglas Channel head, near Kitimat.

child.publications: Fennig, Charles D., M. Paul Lewis & Gary Simons (eds.). 2013. Ethnologue: Languages of the World, Seventeenth edition, Ethnologue: Languages of the World. http://www.ethnologue.com. (09 April, 2013.)

child.pub-comments: 170 speakers (2011 census) out of an ethnic population of 600 (Golla 2007). Shifting to English [eng]. Taught in Kitamaat by University of Northern British Columbia since 1994. Speakers 25 or older; no children read or write the language.
